Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Kinematic and Mechanical Alignment in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Ninety-nine primary TKAs in 95 patients were randomised to either the KA group (n = 49) or the MA group (n = 50).

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients undergoing primary TKA. The study was conducted at a single institution.

Intervention.evidence: In the KA group, patient-specific cutting blocks were manufactured using preoperative MRI data, while the MA group used computer navigation for neutral alignment.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare kinematic alignment (KA) and mechanical alignment (MA) techniques in total knee arthroplasty (TKA) regarding patient-reported outcomes and component alignment.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Oxford Knee Score (OKS) measured preoperatively and at 6 weeks, 6 months, 1 year, and 2 years postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ninety-nine primary TKAs in 95 patients were randomised to either the KA group (n = 49) or the MA group (n = 50).

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant difference was found in 2-year OKS change scores between KA and MA groups (mean difference 1.0, 95% CI, âˆ’1.4 to 3.4, p = 0.4).

Harms.evidence: Complication rates were similar between groups.
